prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "reglet and furniture". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Reglet and Furniture**

'Twas brillig in the printshop's maze,
Where reglet ruled and types aligned,
The furniture, in forms obease,
Twas set just so — divine!

The compositor, with hands a-clatter,
Pierced forms with steady art,
Arranging lines both thick and splatter,
Each word a leader's part.

"Beware the slugs!" the old man grunted,
"Beware the typeface's teeth!
And mind the kerning, lest ye be stunted,
Or letters t’will fall beneath."

He took his pica stick in hand,
And measured each fine space,
While reglets, smooth as dappled sand,
Lay nestled, what a grace!

The furniture, so snugly stacked,
Held gallies with a glare,
And spacers, placed with steady tact,
Allowed for air to share.

Then came the chase, that steadfast frame,
Where metal locked with care,
The reglet's rule and furniture's name,
In order met their fare.

And when the press did turn at last,
The type stood bold and clear,
A printed sheet — the past surpassed,
With reglet and furniture!
label: medium
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title line present before first stanza: "Reglet and Furniture" - clear non-empty title present.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanza count: 8 stanzas total, all quatrains (4 lines each), total stanzas 8 (within 5–8). Meets quota.</C2_think>

Likely no.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme check on lines (2,4) in ≥60% stanzas: rhymes mostly present (maze/divine; art/part; teeth/beneath; hand/grace; glare/share; care/fare; last/clear; surpassed/furniture). Avoids AABB dominance (mostly ABAB or ABCB). Rhymes appear mostly end sounds, though some slant rhymes. Enough stanzas with 2/4 rhyme present (≥5 of 8). Yes.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the opening stanza? No strong content word repetition or refrains linking final stanza back to first stanza lines. Words like "Reglet" and "furniture" appear, but no clear repeated content phrases from first stanza (which mentions brillig and printshop maze), thus no ring composition with ≥2 repeated content words or refrain. No.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Presence of early admonition/warning: yes, stanza 3 contains “Beware the slugs!” and “Beware the typeface's teeth!”, clearly an admonition to the protagonist.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation by the protagonist before encounter: yes, protagonist “took his pica stick in hand,” measured, handled reglets and furniture carefully, preparing the process. Preparation is explicit.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter/confrontation with adversary/obstacle: “Then came the chase” stanza mentions “where metal locked,” “reglet’s rule and furniture’s name, in order met their fare,” implying a confrontation/challenge occurring. Though abstract and metaphorical, there is an encounter present.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action resolving tension: “When the press did turn at last,” and “printed sheet — the past surpassed,” indicating the success/end of challenge. Decisive act is implied via press turning and final print.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return or celebration: final stanza’s positive tone “printed sheet — the past surpassed,” celebrating success, though no explicit “return home” or “jubilation” addressed, still a form of celebratory completion. Counts as yes.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Count of invented coinages distinct from canonical and standard English: “Reglet” and “furniture” are real print terms but used as poetic elements; mostly standard English words with no clear invented coinages distinct enough; “pica stick” is printing terminology but standard. <C14_think>≥2 onomatopoeic bursts: no explicit onomatopoeia like “snicker-snack!” or “burbled” present; words like “clatter” or “turn” are normal verbs, not onomatopoeia bursts. No.</C14_think>
<C15_think>≥2 stanzas show clear alliteration/consonance beyond incidental: some alliteration like "hands a-clatter / steady art" (stanza 2) and “metal locked with care,” “press did turn,” but no strong evidence of clear prominent alliteration/consonance beyond incidental repeats in at least 2 stanzas. Borderline but mostly no.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc beats in canonical order warning → preparation → encounter → decisive act → return celebration: Stanza 3 warning, stanzas 4-5 preparation, stanza 7 encounter, stanza 8 decisive act and celebration. The order aligns well. Yes.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No exact verbatim line matches: no lines exactly match canonical poem lines; all unique wording. Yes.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Distinct canonical tokens ≤8: canonical tokens “brillig”, “slithy”, “toves”, etc., only “brillig” appears once in first stanza; no other canonicals found. Canonical count ≤8, yes.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness: lines length roughly ~8–9 for longer lines and ~5–7 for shorter lines. Mostly consistent with some quatrains alternating longer/shorter line syllables approximately in Jabberwocky style. Yes.</C19_think>

So yes, poem matches topic of printing/typography in Jabberwocky style.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext/coherent implied layer: subtle metaphor of printing as battle/adventure, with “Beware the slugs” and “chase,” underlying theme of craftsmanship and challenge. Yes.</C24_think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "blued screw in a movement". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
**Blued Screw in a Movement**

'Twas blued, and the jeweled gears ground,
In the heart of the ticking land.
All snicked were the pinions fine,
And the plates aligned divine.

Beware the blued screw, my son!
The escapement slack, its doom begun.
Beware the platform, the loose train,
And shun the clanking regulator’s bane!

It clicked! And wast there a whirr,
When the pallet fork hummed with blurr.
It shaved! It shaved in the escape wheel’s din,
For the verge had lost its thin grin.

One, two! One, two! And through the tick,
The blued screw found its click.
And the movement that stood so pure and bold,
Halved its pace in a cogwheel cold.

And hast thou fixed that blued screw, my son?
Come to rest where once it spun.
'Tis taught! 'Tis taught in the horologist’s lore,
That the screw, though blued, shall spin no more.
label: low
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "**Blued Screw in a Movement**" is present before first stanza, non-empty and separate.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas total; all stanzas have 4 lines each (quatrains) and stanza count is between 5 and 8.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter alternation: Most stanzas do not clearly exhibit alternating longer (8-9 syllables) and shorter (5-7 syllables) lines with ≥2 content words difference; pattern inconsistent.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme: rhymes in lines 2 and 4 appear typically present (e.g., begun/bane, spun/more less clear); no obvious AABB dominance; mostly alternating rhyme, but end rhymes are somewhat limited and sometimes imperfect.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the opening with repeated phrase "And hast thou..." and references "blued screw" theme, but no ≥2 repeated content words/phrases exact from first stanza; refrain is loose.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: second stanza clearly warns "Beware the blued screw, my son!" with warnings following, similar to canonical admonition.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation: The third stanza implies some checking or sound ("It clicked!", "pallet fork hummed") suggesting mechanical observation but no clear active preparation (arming, planning) before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter/confrontation: Fourth stanza depicts action "One, two! One, two!" and "blued screw found its click", implying a clear mechanical confrontation with the "blued screw".</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive action: The screw "found its click" and "Halved its pace in a cogwheel cold" indicates a mechanical resolution; the "fixing" or halting of the screw is a decisive action.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return/celebration: The final stanza has a calm tone, 'fixed' screw and "Come to rest", but no jubilant or celebratory tone or clear homecoming acknowledgment as in canonical poem.</C10_think>
<C11_think>There are several invented coinages or unusual compounds (blued, jeweled, snicked, pinions, cogwheel, escapement, pallet fork, verge, horologist’s) but fewer than 8 distinct truly novel coinages; most words are standard or technical.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Not every stanza contains a coinage. Some stanzas use standard English or technical terms; coinage distribution is uneven.</C12_think>
<C13_think>No named non-canonical creature/entity is present central to action; "blued screw" is an object, not a creature; no unique named monster/entity.</C13_think>
<C14_think>No strong onomatopoeic bursts as in canonical (snicker‑snack etc); limited to "clicked" and "whirr" which are mild and indirect sounds, not bursts.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Some alliteration present ("pallet fork hummed with blurr" has consonance), but only in one or two stanzas, not clearly multiple stanzas with prominent alliteration or consonance.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Arc order generally follows canonical order: warning → implied preparation/observation → encounter → decisive action → resolution; somewhat consistent.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No lines verbatim from canonical poem; all original wording.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical tokens from the original poem appear not more than ~5 times (words like "Beware", "my son", "One, two! One, two!"), so canonical budget is ≤8.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable counts approximate: longer lines often 8-9 syllables, shorter lines shorter but not consistently; tighter syllable control not definitive.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety limited: repeated rhymes like "click"/"tick", "spun"/"done" not evident, rhymes look somewhat repeated or limited; rhyme variety under 60%.</C20_think>
<C21_think>No content word clearly overused; moderate lexical repetition.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinages are limited and mostly use related roots (mechanical words derived from similar roots); coinages show little root variety; under 4 distinct roots.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Topic is mechanical "blued screw", consistent throughout; no drifting to other topics; adherence to subject strong.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext or implied motif (e.g., mechanical failure, horologist’s care, inevitability of breakdown) is subtle but detectable; implied tension about mechanism's fate.</C24_think>
</think>

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "murmuration over stubble". Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Murmuration Over Stubble

'Twas murmlight, and the skyming birds
Did glimp and glint in the sighing air;
All flipsey were the stubbled fields,
And the coldsmoke mist hung everywhere.
"Beware the Flickergleam, my child!
The whiskied wings! the darting soar!
Beware the Duskwing, sharp and wild,
And shun the silent Suddenfloor!"

He swindled forth, his brains ablur,
A-swift with dread and belly dreams;
For though the jabberhorns were still,
The whooshing flockfolk heard his screams.
And as he tumbled 'neath their pass,
The murmuration skimmed in thrills—
A sudden pounce, a scatter-mass,
Then silence, save the stubble-chills.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line "Murmuration Over Stubble" is present before the first stanza and non-empty.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 3 stanzas; none have 4 lines (first has 4 lines, second has 4, third has 4 lines actually?), total stanza count is 3, which is less than 5; fail total stanza count requirement.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Check alternating longer/shorter lines with ≥2 content-word difference in ≥60% stanzas: Lines lengths vary but less clear; only 3 stanzas, second stanza lines seem more even; not enough consistent ballad meter alternation; fail.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme in lines 2 and 4 in ≥60% stanzas: First stanza (air/everywhere) rhyme, second stanza (wild/suddenfloor) partial rhyme not strong; third stanza (thrills/stubble-chills) rhyme; 2 out of 3 stanzas have rhyme (≈66.7%); also no AABB dominance; pass.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoing opening with ≥2 repeated content words or clear refrain: No clear ring composition or repeated phrases or content words; fail.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition present: Yes, second stanza, “Beware the Flickergleam, my child!” fits admonition/caution to protagonist early.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation by protagonist present: "He swindled forth, his brains ablur, A-swift with dread and belly dreams;" - some sign of resolve/action before encounter, but no clear tool or plan or waiting shown; borderline but not definitive; fail.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Clear encounter between protagonist and adversary: Yes, stanza 3 describes murmuration flock pouncing/scattering after protagonist tumbled; clear meeting of protagonist and flock (antagonistic obstacle). Pass.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive act resolving central tension: No clear decisive action or slaying present; just protagonist tumbling and flock pouncing; no resolution of conflict shown; fail.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return and celebration: No return or jubilant acknowledgement present; fail.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Distinct invented coinages ≥8: Coinages include murmlight, skyming, flipsey, coldsmoke, Flickergleam, Duskwing, Suddenfloor, jabberhorns, flockfolk, stubble-chills - at least 9 distinct coinages; pass.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains ≥1 coinage: stanza 1 (murmlight, skyming, flipsey, coldsmoke), stanza 2 (Flickergleam, Duskwing, Suddenfloor, jabberhorns, flockfolk), stanza 3 (murmuration, stubble-chills) all have coinages; pass.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Non-canonical creature/entity named and central to action (not ‘Jabberwock’): Flickergleam, Duskwing, Suddenfloor mentioned as creatures; protagonist confronted with murmuration flock (called flockfolk), also jabberhorns mentioned; pass.</C13_think>
<C14_think>At least 2 onomatopoeic bursts: No clear onomatopoeic bursts like snicker-snack or Pop! Hiss!; words like "whooshing" are close but not bursts; fail.</C14_think>
<C15_think>At least 2 stanzas show clear alliteration or consonance beyond incidental: "swindled forth, his brains ablur", "whiskied wings, darting soar", "murmuration skimmed", "suddenfloor", "skyming", "stubbled fields" show some alliteration/consonance; at least 2 stanzas with evident alliteration; pass.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Story arc order (warning → preparation → encounter → decisive action → return/celebration): Warning present, preparation weak or absent, encounter present, no decisive action or return; arc incomplete and out of order; fail.</C16_think>
<C17_think>No verbatim canonical lines: no canonical line exactly repeated; fail if any identical lines; pass.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical token count ≤8: used jabberhorns and murmuration as coinages, no explicit canonical lexicon such as brililg or toves; only "jabber" in jabberhorns but not exactly canonical; count of canonical tokens (like Jubjub, Bandersnatch) zero; pass.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness in quatrain stanzas: Lines vary between approx 7-10 syllables for longer, shorter lines mostly 5-6; first stanza roughly in range, last stanza lines slightly longer than typical shorter line; borderline but no consistent tight pattern ≥60%; fail.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: (2,4) rhymes differ among stanzas; no rhyme end word repeats more than twice; pass.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition guard: No single content word obviously repeated >5 times or >8% of content words; pass.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety ≥4 distinct roots: Coinages formed from distinct roots (murmlight, skyming, flipsey, coldsmoke, Flickergleam, Duskwing, Suddenfloor, jabberhorns, flockfolk, stubble-chills)—clearly diverse roots; pass.</C22_think>
<C23_think>Poem addresses topic of a Carroll-style nonsense/parody with invented creatures and encounter; no explicit topic given, but poem addresses original Jabberwocky-like encounter with new creatures; pass.</C23_think>
<C24_think>Subtext/coherent implied motif beyond surface: minimal subtext; implied fear, nature evasion, but not strongly developed motif or undertone; borderline, leaning no.</C24_think>
